nodes.bodyText: Changes in this file were mostly opportunistic (e.g. s/emailAddress/email/ in method names), but the key need was to add a method supportting conversion from the full GSuite email address (gjordan@fake-research-aou.org) to the username (gjordan).
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,25 +1,29 @@
 package org.pmiops.workbench.google;

nodes.bodyText: I decided this wasn't worth a unit test case... feel free to disagree!
Opportunistic rename – the original var didn't conform to style guidelines, and userInfo is sufficiently precise.
nit: Userinfoplus isn't the most descriptive class name. Maybe oauthInfo? "user" is implied I think.
I agree, but we don't control that class. It's part of Google's OAuth2 implementation.
I understand,  but I'm saying  changing the var  name to  be more descriptive at the  expense of matching the type would help.
A lot of the changes in this file were related to Spring-ifying this test class, and pulling some very common logic into simple helper methods.

Since this is a hierarchical structure, maybe unsafe should be its own section so you don't need a prefix.
Also, what's "unsafe" here? Is it that the user doesn't go through all the right registration steps? Could we not make it safe by synthesizing those, so these test users are more representative?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -87,6 +87,7 @@
     "enableDataUseAgreement": true,
     "enableBetaAccess": false,
     "unsafeAllowSelfBypass": true,
+    "unsafeAllowUserCreationFromGSuiteData": true,

nodes.bodyText: Unsafe has the same meaning as the other unsafe flag: unsafe to have this flag turned on in production. Which is why we have unit tests to help prevent this from accidentally happening.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -87,6 +87,7 @@
     "enableDataUseAgreement": true,
     "enableBetaAccess": false,
     "unsafeAllowSelfBypass": true,
+    "unsafeAllowUserCreationFromGSuiteData": true,

nodes.bodyText: Good call, done. (Is there a good way to get IntelliJ to offer to auto-import the Truth8 version when I want to use this pattern?)
Maybe add a comment that this "email" is what we now call username.
aside: a builder would be nice for this class.
this is the only place I've seen gSuiteEmailAddress instead of username. Is the idea here that there may not actually be a user yet?

Mostly for consistency and clarity within this file, since username within this service has an existing meaning (which is the GSuite email without the domain suffix). It looks like it would be possible to drop that meaning from this service – IMO not a huge win, I'll opt to leave as-is.

In that case, I'd rename username in this class then to usernamePrefix or some such.
FWIW I rarely absorb code a file at a time. It's 80% hopping via IDE linkage between occurrences. Email already means two things. If username means two things, then we're in trouble.

I was about to punt on this, but when I looked through even this file I found there was some inconsistency in how username alone was being used. I took a broader pass at cleaning up the naming in existing methods too (turns out most of these are only used in one place, so the surface area was relatively small). Feels like an improvement, as long as I didn't break anything. PTAL.

nit: If we need to do much with this API, a helper class might...help. For example
Optional<String> getStringField(customSchemaMap, schemaName, fieldName)
nit: I prefer very small names for lambda arguments, especially if they go out of scope in the same line.
If we had a clear style rule one way or another, I'd follow it! For now I'm sticking with my general aesthetic, which is longer-but-clearer parameter names.
super nit: might be faster to do this via a query directly on the DAO, but with a small # of institutions it doesn't much matter.
Good point – I'll avoid premature optimization in this case (especially since we do a full read of institutions in a few other places in this service).
nit: not sure if "dev" is an approved abbrev.
I think dev is pretty well-established usage – e.g. project.rb dev-up
Might as well use the full class name createUserFromUserinfoplus or leave it out, i.e. createUser().
Yeah, I agree this isn't super consistent. Just createUser seems like an all around improvement – done.
It seems awkward that this service needs to know anything about institutions. It seems like the UserService should have all the machinery necessary to affiliate the user.
nit: you can use the new Optional<DbUser> getByUsername(String username) on UserService to avoid the null comparison.

I made a good-faith attempt to use Optional patterns here, but I couldn't come up with a solution that wasn't more awkward than the current conditional logic. The challenge is that we want to either provide a non-null DbUser object if the flag allows it, or return false, which isn't easily expressed within chained optional lambdas.
There was a bug in my existing logic though, which I did fix (pushing new commit in a minute). So there's that...

Yeah, it's hard to write awkward logic with Optionals, which is kind of the point.
FWIW you can do DbUser user  = getByUsername(String username).orElseGet(() -> userService.createServiceAccountUser(userName)); to clean up one  conditional. Or better yet put a getOrCreateServiceAccount(String username) on the UserService.
for later: it would be good to audit this...though if it never happens in production 🤷 .
You could make this a bean I think.
Not sure why?
Oh  if this class doesn't use a user provider then I guess t that doesn't make sense.
nit: new convention is to have a mock prefix for mock instance variables, since the call site can be a long way from the declaration.
👍  I think creating an API style guide will be a helpful place to document conventions like this, especially when they're a change from much of our existing code.
I could spend time on that. In most  instances folks are ok making little improvements like that without a guide. I've just been changing them all whenever I edit a test class.
Are there no other side effects to verify here?
The Mockito stubs above pretty much cover the function under test line-by-line... I couldn't really think of anything else that wouldn't be super redundant.
OK. I was going to  see if any other fields on the  created user could  be validated, but it's mocks all  the way down.
Thanks for this improvement. Will reference this in the post-mortem.
